tn.text: Paul tells the believers he has sent Timothy to strengthen their faith.

tn.ref: we could no longer bear it
tn.text: "we could no longer endure worrying about you"

tn.ref: good to be left behind at Athens alone
tn.text: "good for Silvanus and me to stay behind in Athens"
"proper" or "reasonable"
This is a city in the Achaia province, which is now modern-day Greece. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These two expressions both describe Timothy.
To be "shaken" is an idiom for being afraid. AT: "no one would be frightened away from trusting in Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Paul assumes that everyone knows that it was God who appointed them. This can be made explicit. AT: "God has appointed us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Certainly" or "Surely"
"to be mistreated by others"

tn.ref: I could no longer stand it
tn.text: Paul was describing his own emotions by using an idiom. AT: "I could not longer wait patiently" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
It is implied that Paul sent Timothy. This can be made explicit. AT: "I sent Timothy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"our hard work among you" or "our teaching among you"
"useless"
Paul tells his readers about Timothy's report after he returned from visiting them.
The word "us" refers to Paul and Silvanus. (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: the good news of your faith
tn.text: It is understood that this refers to faith in Christ. This can be made explicit. AT: "a good report of your faith"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
When they think of Paul, they always have good thoughts about him.
"you desire to see us"
Here "brothers" means fellow Christians.
This refers to faith in Christ. This can be made explicit. AT: "because of your faith in Christ" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: in all our distress and affliction
tn.text: The word "affliction" explains why they are in "distress." AT: "in all our distress caused by our afflictions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This is an idiom that expresses living a satisfied life. AT: "we are very encouraged" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: if you stand firm in the Lord
tn.text: To "stand firm" is an idiom meaning to continue being faithful. AT: "if you continue to trust in the Lord" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: For what thanks can we give to God for you, for all the joy that we have before our God over you?
tn.text: This rhetorical question can be expressed as a statement. AT: "We cannot thank God enough for what he has done for you! We greatly rejoice over you when we pray to our God!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Paul speaks as if he and his companions were physically in God's presence. He is probably referring to the activity of praying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here an exaggeration is used to show how often Paul prays. AT: "Frequently" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"fervently"
The word "face" refers to their whole person. AT: "visit you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
In these verses, the word "our" does not always refer to the same group of people. Please see the translation notes for specifics.

tn.ref: May our God ... our Lord Jesus
tn.text: Paul includes the Thessalonian believers with his ministry team. (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
"We pray that our God"

Paul speaks as if he wants God to show him and his companions the route to take to visit the Thessalonian Christians. He means that he wants God to make it possible for them to do so. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "our" refers to Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy but not the Thessalonian believers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
Here "himself" refers back to "Father" for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
Paul speaks of love as an object that one could obtain more of. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul refers to the "heart" as the center of one's beliefs and convictions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: at the coming of our Lord Jesus
tn.text: "when Jesus comes back to earth"
"with all those who belong to him"
